questions.text: A 68-year-old man came with complaints of long-standing arthralgia in the knee. On examination, bluish-black scleral patches were seen as shown. On further inquiry, he says that the urine turns black on exposure to air. Accumulation of which of the following compounds caused this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of alkaptonuria and the pathological discoloration shown in the image is ochronosis. Accumulation of the compound benzoquinone acetate has caused this condition.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, the enzyme which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme will lead to the accumulation of homogentisic acid that  oxidizes into benzoquinone acetate. Later, benzoquinone acetate polymerizes and binds to tissues (especially collagen fibres).

This oxidation process produces free radicals that cause tissue damage and incite inflammation. Additionally, the excess homogentisic acid is excreted in the urine. This results in the classical clinical features of alkaptonuria such as- 

  • Homogentisic aciduria- Black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 
  • Ochronosis- Bluish-black discoloration of tissues mostly involving ear cartilage, ocular tissue, the skin of the eyelids, forehead, cheeks, and hands, nail beds, and even deeper structures such as the larynx and tendons.
  • Arthropathy- Debilitating arthralgia or arthritis that may be seen after the fourth or fifth decade.

Other options-

Option B- Methyl malonyl-CoA is seen in urine (methylmalonic aciduria) due to deficiency of methylmalonyl Co A mutase which is a vitamin b12 dependent enzyme.

Option C- Increased orotic acid in the blood and urine is seen in ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.

Option D- Sulfogalactosylceramide is accumulated in metachromatic leukodystrophy due to deficiency of Aryl-sulfatase A.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese woman presented with a low-grade fever and colicky pain in the right hypochondrium. Scleral icterus and tenderness in the right hypochondrium were noted. Ultrasound showed the following finding in the enlarged common bile duct (measuring 9 mm). Investigations reveal deranged liver function tests. Which of the following would be best suited for her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasonograph indicate a diagnosis of choledocholithiasis. The next best step in the management of this patient is endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).

Symptoms of fever and obstructive jaundice symptoms such as scleral icterus, light-colored stools, and dark-colored urine point toward a diagnosis of choledocholithiasis.

The first investigation, in this case, is a USG to look for biliary duct dilation and determine whether it is intra- or extrahepatic. Once this is confirmed, ERCP can be done as it can remove the stone without operative intervention. 

Common indications for ERCP:

  • Relief of biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease (can present as unexplained jaundice)
  • Biliary drainage
  • Biliary stenting for strictures and leakage
  • Biliary or pancreatic ductal system tissue sampling
  • Balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures
  • Sphincterotomy
  • Sphincter of Oddi manometry

ERCP utilizes a side-viewing endoscope through which it identifies and is able to cannulate the Ampulla of Vater. A water-soluble contrast is then injected into the common bile duct. It helps in identifying stones or strictures.

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is used in case of unsuccessful ERCP or anatomical difficulty for EŖCP.

The below image shows a schematic diagram of ERCP:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs act on the same receptor but have opposite effects?
questions.solution:
Diazoxide and nateglinide act on K-ATP channels (potassium-ATP channels) on the beta cells of pancreas. Nateglinide causes these channels to close, while diazoxide keeps them open.

Closure of these channels eventually results in insulin release, hence nateglinide is used in diabetics. Diazoxide is used in insulinomas, because it inhibits insulin release by keeping these channels open.

Other options:

Option A: Octreotide is a synthetic surrogate of somatostatin. They both inhibit growth hormone release. Since octreotide is more potent and with increased duration of action, it is preferred for use in acromegaly and secretory diarrheas.

Option B: Thioridazine and haloperidol are D2 (dopamine) receptor blockers. These are typical antipsychotics and used to treat schizophrenia and similar psychotic conditions.

Option C: Pioglitazone is a PPAR gamma agonist used in diabetes, while gemfibrozil is a PPAR alpha agonist, used in hyperlipidemia. (PPAR: peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor).

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient came to dermatology OPD with the clinical features shown in the image below. The likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows bluish patchy skin lesions on the face in the region of the first and second branches of the trigeminal nerve and sclera which are suggestive of nevus of Ota.

Nevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis. A large number of elongated dendritic melanocytes can be seen scattered among collagen bundles mainly of the superficial dermis.

It affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye. Distributed along with the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve.

Most lesions are present at birth or develop during the first year of life, increasing in size and number in subsequent years. Lesions are more common in females and in Asians.

Q‐switched laser systems are the first-line treatment, as they achieve higher rates of pigment clearing.

Other options:

Option A- Nevus of Ito appears as a  unilateral, blue‐greyish macular discoloration location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves- acromioclavicular region.

 

Option B- A compound nevus is an acquired melanocytic nevus. It is a slightly raised, oval, or round symmetrical papule. This nevus is also pigmented, with shades of brown according to the skin color of the patient.

 

Option D- Hypomelanosis of Ito refers to the skin abnormalities characterized by unusual unilateral or bilateral cutaneous macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches, corresponding to the lines of Blaschko. It is often associated with epilepsy and mental retardation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to your clinic with complaints of pain in her right knee for the past month. She is the sports captain at her school and has been recently practicing for her state-level basketball tournament. She says that the pain increases while playing but there is no pain at rest. Her pulse rate is 80 beats per minute, BP is 100/78 mm of Hg and her temperature is 98.3F. On examination, there is a swelling distal to the right knee joint line. There is pain on active extension against resistance. Her blood-work is normal. You order an X-ray to further investigate. Which among the following X-ray findings are you most likely to see in this patient?

choices.text: Horizontal fracture line across the patella
Traction injury of the tibial tuberosity
Soft tissue swelling with abnormal downward angulation of patella
Central area of radiolucency with a surrounding thick rim of reactive bone sclerosis

questions.solution:
The X-ray image will show a traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter Disease, also known as apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity.

The condition is usually seen in young adolescents and may not be associated with any injury.

The presenting feature is a painful lump below the knee joint. On examination, the lump is tender and its situation over the tibial tuberosity is diagnostic of the disease.

It is usually treated conservatively, with rest and restriction of activity or cast immobilization for 3-6 weeks. 

Osgood-Schlatter Disease-

 

Other options-

Option A- A horizontal fracture line with displaced or undisplaced fragments is seen in transverse fracture of the patella. It may be seen in falls onto the knee or due to indirect forces causing a sudden, forceful contraction of the quadriceps. Physical examination will show a swollen knee with a gap in between the patellar segments with hemarthrosis. Displaced transverse patellar fractures are treated with tension band wiring in a 'figure-of-8' configuration. 

 

Option C- Soft tissue swelling with abnormal downward angulation of the patella is suggestive of rupture of the quadriceps muscle/tendon. It is more commonly seen in the elderly. On examination, a palpable gap in the quadriceps tendon may be felt proximal to the patella, and the patella can be displaced inferiorly and active knee extension will be impossible in a complete rupture. It is managed with a primary repair with reattachment to the patella.

 

Option D-  Central area of radiolucency with a surrounding thick rim of reactive bone sclerosis is suggestive of osteomyelitis. It is unlikely in this case, as patients with osteomyelitis often present with fever, chills, and fatigue with signs of local inflammation, with or without local discharge. Laboratory workup is also likely to reveal anemia and leukocytosis.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old female has a history of sudden unpredictable episodes of sweating, palpitations, and chest tightness with an impending sense of doom. She often avoids social situations and public forums due to fear of these symptoms. She was recently made to stand-in for the team-lead at her work. During one of her presentations, she develops palpitations and dizziness. She is immediately brought to the emergency room. Her pulse rate is 120 beats/minute and her respiratory rate is 26/min. Which of the following will be seen on arterial blood gas analysis in this patient?

1: pH: 7.49, PaCO2: 28 mm of Hg, HCO3-: 20 mEq/L

2: pH: 7.52, PaCO2: 44 of Hg, HCO3-: 30 mEq/L

3: pH: 7.32, PaCO2: 50mm of Hg, HCO3-:  20 mEq/L

4: pH: 7.32, PaCO2: 37 mm of Hg, HCO3-:  18 mEq/L
questions.solution:
A pH of 7.49, PaCO2 of 28 mm of Hg, and HCO3- of 20 mEq/L signifies respiratory alkalosis which will be seen in this patient with hyperventilation on arterial blood gas analysis. 

In respiratory alkalosis, the primary change is a decrease in PaCO2 due to alveolar hyperventilation. 

The patient's symptoms of episodes of sudden palpitations, sweating, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and an impending sense of doom are suggestive of panic disorder. Hyperventilation associated with anxiety and panic disorder causes carbon dioxide washout. This results in decreased PaCO2. In acute respiratory alkalosis like anxiety-induced hyperventilation, HCO3- levels remain normal due to delayed metabolic compensation. This increases the HCO3-/PaCO2 thus increasing the arterial pH.

Other causes of respiratory alkalosis include:

  • Central nervous system stimulation - pain, fever, encephalitis, tumor, trauma
  • Hypoxemia or tissue hypoxia - High altitude, pneumonia, pulmonary edema, aspiration, and severe anemia
  • Drugs: Salicylates
  • Stimulation of chest receptors - Hemothorax, flail chest, cardiac failure, pulmonary embolism
  • Others: Pregnancy, mechanical hyperventilation, heat exposure

Other options:

Option B: A pH of 7.52, PaCO2 of 44 of Hg, HCO3- of 30 mEq/L signifies metabolic alkalosis. There is increased blood arterial pH, as a result of a net gain of HCO3- or a loss of nonvolatile acid from the extracellular fluid. Compensatory alveolar hypoventilation occurs and causes an increase in PaCO2. Common examples include vomiting, gastric aspiration, diuretic use, and milk-alkali syndrome.

Option C: A pH of 7.32, PaCO2 of 50mm of Hg, HCO3- of 20 mEq/L signifies respiratory acidosis. There is decreased blood arterial pH as a result of an increase in PaCO2 following alveolar hypoventilation. In acute respiratory acidosis, HCO3- levels remain normal due to delayed metabolic compensation. Examples include opioid overdose, severe sepsis, airway obstruction, ARDS, and respiratory muscle fatigue (polio, myasthenia)

Option D: A pH of 7.32, PaCO2 of 37 mm of Hg, HCO3- of 18 mEq/L signifies metabolic acidosis. There is decreased blood arterial pH because of an increase in endogenous acid production (Example: Diabetic ketoacidosis, increased lactate in sepsis), loss of HCO3- (Example: diarrhea), or low excretion of net acid by kidneys (Example: chronic kidney disease). Respiratory compensation (alveolar hyperventilation) occurs causing a decrease in PaCO2.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: The v-wave of the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is due to-

choices.text: Venous filling of the right atrium
Passive emptying of the right atrium
Bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium

questions.solution:
The v-wave of the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is due to the venous filling of the right atrium.

The JVP is ideally examined in the internal jugular vein (IJV). IJV lies anteriorly to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and it should be examined in good lighting at a 45° angle. It reflects the right atrial pressure.

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

questions.text: A woman from rural South America presents with shortness of breath and palpitations. Examination of the eye is shown in the image given below. Echocardiography reveals biventricular dilatation with massive cardiac enlargement. Which vector is most likely responsible for transmitting this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with an image showing Romana’s sign and echo findings of dilated cardiomyopathy, are suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, transmitted by the reduviid bug.

Chagas disease is a zoonotic disease caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi. It is endemic to north, central, and south America. It is transmitted by the bite of a reduviid bug/ kissing bug.

Trypanosoma cruzi exists in three forms:

  • Epimastigotes- in the reduviid bug
  • Trypomastigotes- in the bloodstream
  • Amastigotes- intracellular replicating form

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, chagoma (localised subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and the Romaña's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen in the acute phase. 

The chronic phase is characterised by the following findings:

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement. This leads to leading to congestive heart failure, presenting as shortness of breath. Endomyocardial biopsy shows fibrosis and the presence of intracellular parasites.
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating trypomastigotes on microscopy of blood smears or polymerase chain reactions during the acute phase. In the chronic phase, detection of anti-T. cruzi IgG or endomyocardial biopsy is helpful.

Treatment of Chagas disease is most effective when administered early in the course of infection and has a lesser efficacy in chronic Chagas. Benznidazole and nifurtimox can be used for the treatment.

The image given below shows a reduviid bug.

Other options:

Option A: Dermacentor tick is a type of hard tick responsible for transmitting rocky mountain spotted fever.

Option B: Soft ticks are known to transmit relapsing fever.

Option D: Tsetse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei gambiense that cause African sleeping sickness.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common extracranial solid tumor in the pediatric age group?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children and the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in infants. It is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral nervous system.

The signs and symptoms depend on the location of the tumor and the extent of the disease. Neuroblastomas originating from the superior cervical ganglion can present with Horner syndrome.

Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following

  • Fever
  • Irritability
  • Failure to thrive
  • Bone pain
  • Cytopenia
  • Bluish subcutaneous nodules
  • Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses

Rapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus), and ataxia are characteristic of the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is a paraneoplastic syndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastomas.

Some neuroblastomas may undergo spontaneous regression, whereas some may be unresponsive to therapy and run a very aggressive course.

questions.text: A 43-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency with an altered sensorium after he had three episodes of vomiting bright red blood. On arrival, his pulse rate was 110 beats per minute and blood pressure was 80/50 mm of Hg. The patient was immediately intubated and stabilized with IV fluids. Intravenous octreotide was initiated. After the patient was stabilized, an endoscopy was performed which showed multiple bleeding esophageal varices. There was no evidence of esophageal tears or gastric and duodenal ulcers.  Band ligation therapy was performed on endoscopy. Abdominal ultrasound was done and showed a shrunken, nodular liver, splenomegaly, and moderate ascites. Which of the following medicines would be best suited in this patient to decrease the risk of recurrent variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Non-selective beta-blockers, like Propranolol, can be used to reduce the risk of recurrent bleeding in patients with esophageal varices.

Esophageal varices are a known complication of portal hypertension secondary to liver cirrhosis. Treatment for esophageal varices can be broadly divided into primary prophylaxis and prevention of rebleeding.

Primary prophylaxis is used for patients who have not had acute bleeding but have evidence of esophageal varices on endoscopy. Prevention of rebleeding in patients who have already had an acute bleeding episode is called prevention of rebleeding or secondary prophylaxis. 

Prophylactic therapies to reduce recurrent variceal bleeding include:

  • Non-selective beta-blockers like propranolol, nadolol - used in the medical prophylaxis of esophageal varices as they lower the pressure in the splanchnic system (portal venous pressure)
  • Endoscopic variceal ligation - indicated in patients with large varices and a high risk of bleeding

In this patient with altered sensorium, intubation is done to reduce the risk of aspiration. IV fluids and blood products are started to stabilize the patient hemodynamically. Antibiotics must be started simultaneously as they are known to reduce the risk of infection, rebleeding, and mortality. Injection Octreotide (somatostatin analogue) or other vasoconstrictors like terlipressin (vasopressin analogue) is started through intravenous route for patients who are not stable to undergo endoscopy as it is known to reduce the portal venous pressure and control the bleeding. Balloon tamponade (image below) can be used in patients who are not able to undergo endoscopic therapy. Once the patient is stabilized, endoscopic band ligation is done to control the acute bleeding varices.

Other options:

Option A: Spironolactone, a diuretic is used in the management of ascites in portal hypertension. It does not have any role in preventing variceal bleed.

Option B: Although this patient is expected to have decreased clotting factors and increased prothrombin time, it is due to the decreased synthetic function of the liver secondary to cirrhosis (reduced hepatic mass) and supplementation of Vitamin K will not improve the coagulation. Vitamin K supplementation will not help in preventing rebleeding from esophageal varices.

Option C: Proton-pump inhibitors like Rabeprazole are used to prevent bleeding from gastric or duodenal ulcers. Although they have a role in the management of this patient, propranolol, would be the most beneficial.

questions.text: Which of the following glands is involved in the chronic non-suppurative lipogranulomatous inflammatory condition that presents as shown below?
questions.solution:
The chalazion, shown in the image above, is a chronic non-suppurative lipogranulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland.

Retention of the meibomian gland secretions may sometimes lead to a granulomatous reaction in the same. Chalazion may be single or multiple. Although they may reduce in size over the course of few months, the complete spontaneous resolution does not occur, and therefore might require intervention. 

Treatment of chalazion includes injection of intralesional triamcinolone or curettage.

Sometimes, the chalazion may become secondarily infected and forms the hordeolum internum which is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland, associated with blockage of the duct. It presents with a swelling similar to a chalazion, but more inflamed with pus pointing on the conjunctival surface. It can be treated conservatively with oral antibiotics and hot fomentation or with an incision and drainage.

An image of hordeolum internum is shown below- 

 

Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of Zeis gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilia. The entire lid margin may be erythematous. Treatment is with antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done. 

 

The gland of Wolfring and gland of Krause are the accessory conjunctival glands and are not involved in chalazion.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old female patient has not attained menarche. Examination reveals short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, widely spaced nipples, no axillary or pubic hair, and normal external genitalia. USG abdomen shows a small uterus and streak ovaries. FSH and LH are increased. What is the likely cause of amenorrhea?

USG - Ultrasound

FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone

LH - Luteinizing hormone
questions.solution:
The likely cause of amenorrhea in this patient is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. 

Primary amenorrhea refers to the failure of onset of menstruation, beyond the age of 16 years regardless of the development of secondary sexual characteristics. This patient's clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome. Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO).

In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) are indicative of the cause of hypogonadism. Increased levels of FSH and LH as seen in this patient are indicative of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is defined as 1) a decrease or absence in ovarian function and 2) due to absent negative sex-steroid feedback. 

The pathophysiology in Turner's syndrome is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism where there is oocyte atresia and the replacement of ovaries by fibrous streaks. This causes a decrease in serum estrogen levels which by negative feedback causes a rise in gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), FSH, and LH (gonadotropic hormones) as seen in this patient. Hypogonadism with a rise in gonadotropic hormones is known as hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Other options-

Option (B): Secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism patients also present with primary ovarian failure with increased levels of FSH and LH. Secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is seen in damage to the gonads as seen post-chemotherapy, radiation, infection, or in autoimmune disorders. This patient has no history suggestive of a secondary cause.

Options (C and D): Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism results when there is a primary abnormality in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Loss of hypothalamic function causes a decrease in the production of GnRH or pituitary dysfunction causes decreased production of FSH and LH which results in decreased ovarian function and reduced serum estrogen levels. It can be divided into:

  • Inherited hypothalamic abnormalities: Kallmann's syndrome (Option C)
  • Acquired (functional) hypothalamic dysfunction: eating disorders, in patients who exercise excessively, and during periods of stress (Option D). Although this patient is an athlete, her FSH and LH levels are increased suggesting hypergonadotropism.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not suggestive of antemortem hanging?

choices.text: Multiple bruises on neck with absence of vital reaction
Dilation of one eye and other eye being closed
Area of hypostasis limited to legs and hands with a pale face

questions.solution:
In the case of antemortem hanging, injuries are associated with the presence of a vital reaction. 

Eyes may show the following findings in antemortem hanging:

  • La facies sympathique- in case of hanging, one of the eyes may be opened with dilated pupil, while the other eye may be closed. This occurs due to the pressure of the ligature knot on the cervical sympathetic ganglia in the neck. Thus, on the side on which the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic ganglia, the eye remains open with dilatation of its pupil. It is a sign of antemortem hanging.
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhages
  • Prominent eyeballs

Other findings seen in antemortem hanging:

  • Post-mortem hypostasis- present in the legs and hands
  • Petechial hemorrhages- these are usually the exception, rather than the rule
  • In most cases the face is pale, in some cases it may be congestion due to venous occlusion
  • Ligature mark- above the thyroid cartilage and incomplete
  • Soft tissue hemorrhage may be seen.
  • Laryngeal fractures- fractures of the hyoid and thyroid may be seen
  • Amussat sign- damage to intima and media of the carotid artery
  • Simon's sign- hemorrhages on the anterior aspects of intervertebral discs
  • Dribbling of saliva- It is often found dribbling from the angle of the mouth, opposite to the side of the knot. This may be due to stimulation of salivary glands or congestive hypoxia. Salivation may not occur when the death is due to vagal inhibition or injury to the spinal cord. Evidence of dried marks of dribbling saliva is suggestive of antemortem hanging but its absence alone will not suggest that the body was suspended after the death.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a cold nodule on a radio-iodine scan was taken for thyroidectomy surgery. During the operation, the young surgeon accidentally cut the marked nerve on the left side. Postoperatively the patient develops hoarseness of voice. On examination, the affected vocal cord was in a paramedian position and did not move laterally during deep inspiration. The patient was advised speech therapy. This nerve injury had resulted in an impairment of the function of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the gross image points towards a diagnosis of left recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. All laryngeal muscles are supplied by the ipsilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), except cricothyroid which is supplied by the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN). Both SLN and RLN are branches of the vagus nerve.

The recurrent laryngeal nerves (RLN) on the right and the left side follow different courses-

  • Right RLN takes origin in the root of the neck, winds around the first part of the subclavian artery, and then ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove. 
  • Left RLN takes origin in the thorax, winds around the arch of the aorta, and then ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove. Since it has a longer course, it is more likely to be injured.

In case of RLN injury during surgery, if both ends are identified, they should be reanastomosed. If a length of the nerve has been excised during surgery, anastomosis with ansa cervicalis maybe considered. This does not return the mobility of the vocal cords, however neurological input is maintained.

In unilateral RLN palsy, the normal vocal cord crosses the midline and comes closer to the paralyzed one during speech output, as a compensatory measure. This improves the voice over time without any surgical intervention. However, in the case of a persistent defect after a wait of 6-12 months, a type 1 laryngoplasty maybe considered.

 

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman, Mrs. Veena, was brought to your office by her son for a routine check-up. On asking if they had any concerns, he says that his mother was previously very outgoing but has preferred being alone for the past few years. She has stopped attending social events with her friends, because she says that she cannot understand them anymore. She avoids interacting with people and only interacts with her son if he is speaking to her when they are alone. Even during such interactions, she asks him to repeat what he has said multiple times. There are no other complaints. On performing a quick tuning fork test, you find that the Rinne test is positive on both sides (AC>BC), and there is no lateralization on Weber's test. Audiometry results are pending. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette along with tuning fork test findings suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss points towards a diagnosis of presbycusis. It is a type of sensorineural hearing loss associated with the physiological aging process in the ear.

The pathogenesis of Presbycusis includes-

  • Degeneration of the organ of Corti
  • Degeneration of the spiral ganglion
  • Degeneration of the stria vascularis
  • Stiffening of the basilar membrane.

Clinically, it usually manifests in elderly adults over 65 years of age. It is gradually progressive and tends to affect the higher frequencies first. Characteristically, patients with presbycusis have significant difficulty hearing in the presence of background noise. Additionally, patients with presbycusis may also have a paradoxical hypersensitivity to loud sounds. This is due to the recruitment phenomenon. They may also have tinnitus. It significantly affects the quality of life and patients tend to present with progressive social withdrawal. 

On examination, tuning fork tests will show a picture of symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss with

  • Positive Rinne's test in both ears, meaning the air conduction is better than bone conduction (AC>BC) in both ears
  • Weber's test will show no lateralization, meaning the sound is heard equally on both sides. 

Diagnosis can be confirmed with audiometry. Treatment of presbycusis mainly includes using a hearing aid. 

Other options- All of the given options, except for presbycusis typically cause a conductive type of hearing loss. Tuning fork tests in a conductive hearing loss will show Rinne's negative i.e., BC>AC. Weber's test will show lateralization to the diseased ear. 

Option A - Chronic suppurative otitis media will present with a history of ear discharge with a conductive type of hearing loss.

Option B - Impacted ear wax completely occluding the external ear canal is a common cause of conductive hearing loss.

Option D - Otosclerosis is a disease of the otic capsule that usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss. Patients with otosclerosis characteristically hear better in noisy than in quiet surroundings (Paracusis Willisii). Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne's test i.e. BC > AC. Weber's may be central as this is typically symmetrical.

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with endoscopic biopsy findings showing signet ring cells is suggestive of diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

Gastric adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy of the stomach and constitutes more than 90% of all gastric cancers. Based on the gross appearance, the gastric adenoma is classified into two types:

  • Diffuse type, which is characterized by infiltrates and thickening of the gastric wall.
  • Intestinal type, which is characterized by bulky masses

Diffuse adenocarcinoma:

In diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma, the wall of the stomach is thickened and firm, accounting for the radiologic “leather bottle” appearance as shown in the image below. When the entire stomach is involved, the term linitis plastica is applied.

Majority of the gastric cancers are not hereditary. However, in some cases with a family history, the condition is usually associated with loss-of-function mutation of the CDH-1 gene, which encodes for E-cadherin. The loss of E-cadherin plays a key role in the pathogenesis of diffuse gastric cancer.

The invading tumor cells induce extensive fibrosis in the submucosa and muscularis of the stomach wall. Signet ring cells are so named because intracellular mucin displaces the nuclei to the periphery of the tumor cells. Gastric carcinomas and linitis plastica, in particular, have a poor prognosis.

The above H&E-stained smear shows normal gastric mucosa (red arrow) and the characteristic signet cells (green arrows) in a patient with diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma. Management of gastric adenocarcinoma is done by radical or subtotal gastrectomy. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy should be given as it improves survival. In the case of advanced disease, palliative treatment should be considered with chemotherapy alone or in combination with procedures relieving the gastric obstruction.

Other options:

Option A- Menetrier's disease is a rare disorder characterized by massive overgrowth of mucous cells (foveolar cells) lining the stomach, resulting in large gastric folds. They usually present with epigastric pain, diarrhea, hypoproteinemia, and hypochlorhydria. 

Option C- Gastric ulcer would be seen as discontinuation in the epithelium. Moreover, spiral-shaped H.pylori would be seen on the mucosal surface on histopathology.

Option D- Gastric antral vascular ectasia is seen as longitudinal erythematous stripes of edematous mucosa alternating with paler mucosa. Histologically it shows reactive gastropathy with dialted capillaries showing fibrin thrombi.

questions.text: Shanti is a 26-year-old homemaker. She is pregnant for the first time and very cautious about her and her baby's health. She is currently in her 6th month of gestation and presented for TT immunization. On examination, there are no danger signs of pregnancy, fetal growth is adequate and her vitals are within the normal range.  You should advise the following regarding her nutrition except?

choices.text: Take one extra meal daily to make up for increase in calories by 350 Kilo Calories per day
Salt restriction to be practised to prevent gestational hypertension
Take Iron, folic acid tablets once daily after meal and calcium tablets twice daily at different times
To take daal or eggs as per preference to increase protein intake by about 7g daily

questions.solution:
No convincing evidence exists that dietary salt reduction helps in the prevention or management of hypertension during pregnancy. Salt intake should be continued as for a non-pregnant female (<5g salt/<2g Sodium). 

In the given case of a pregnant lady in her second trimester, the following advice needs to be given-

  • An addition of 350 kcal/day is recommended during pregnancy which can be done by taking nutrient-dense foods or by taking one extra meal daily
  • Protein intake should be increased by 0.5g/day in 1st trimester, 9.5g/day in the 2nd trimester, and 22.7 g/day in 3rd trimester
  • Visible fat intake should be increased to 30g/day
  • To take seasonal fruits and vegetables to make up for micronutrients and dietary fiber
  • 8-12 glasses of water per day to prevent constipation
  • Iron-Folic acid tablets to be taken once daily as prescribed. Oral chewable tablets containing 500mg calcium and 250IU vitamin D3 to be taken twice daily. Iron and calcium preparations to be taken at different times as calcium inhibits iron absorption.

  • Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought by his mother with a 2-month history of an enlarging scalp lesion associated with pain. There is associated generalized lymphadenopathy. There is no history of trauma to the head or scalp. An X-ray of the skull is done to reveal punched-out lytic lesions. A biopsy of the skull lesion is done and electron micrographic findings are shown below. The condition occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, whose normal function is ________?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the x-ray findings of punched out lytic lesion and Birbeck granules on Electron microscopy is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). The condition occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells whose normal function is to present antigens.

LCH is a rare histiocytic disorder characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions that can infiltrate nearly every organ, most notably the skin (of the scalp), lungs, thymus, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. LCH is so named because of its resemblance to the Langerhan’s cells, which are specialized dendritic cells found in the skin and mucosa.

 It can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease)
  • Unifocal and multifocal uni system Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma)
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (“coffee-bean” appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. The specific markers for LCH are CD1a and langerin (CD207)

On electron microscopy, the presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic. Birbeck granules are pentalaminar tubules, often with a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket-like appearance, which contains the protein langerin (CD207).

 

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy came to the OPD with a neck swelling. The boy is tall, with long slender fingers, a pigeon chest, and a high-arched palate. There were multiple sessile, painless swellings in the oral cavity. The patient's father has recently had episodes of throbbing headache, palpitations, and dizziness associated with a rise in blood pressure and was diagnosed with an adrenal tumor. The patient's paternal aunt died of thyroid malignancy. On examination, his pulse rate was 88 beats per minute and blood pressure was 128/72 mm of Hg. Neck examination revealed a  firm and mobile swelling extending from the midline to the anterior border of sternocleidomastoid and extending from 3 cm below the hyoid to 2 cm above the suprasternal notch.  Biopsy from the patient's thyroid gland was done under ultrasound guidance and is as shown below. What is the type of thyroid tumor?
questions.solution:
The given histopathology picture shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells which is characteristic of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC).

Medullary carcinoma tumors of the thyroid are neuroendocrine tumors that are derived from parafollicular C cells, that secrete calcitonin.

Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells which form nests, trabeculae, or follicles. Amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules are present in the stroma. Calcitonin in the tumor cells and stroma is easily demonstratable by immunohistochemistry.

Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associated with familial multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome: MEN 2A and MEN 2B. Patients with sporadic MTC present at an older age, whereas patients with familial MTC usually present at a younger age. They frequently present as a neck mass that may be associated with cervical lymphadenopathy. With the enlargement of the nodule patients may have dysphagia and dyspnea. 

In this patient with marfanoid habitus (increased height, long slender fingers, pigeon chest, crowded teeth, and high arch palate) and multiple oral mucosal neuromas (sessile painless swellings), a medullary carcinoma thyroid rises a suspicion of MEN 2B syndrome. This is supported by the family history of pheochromocytoma (repeated history of episodic headaches, palpitations, and rise in blood pressure) in the father and malignant thyroid cancer (probably medullary carcinoma) in paternal aunt supports the diagnosis of MEN 2B. MEN 2B is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and due to a mutation in RET oncogene.

Option A: Papillary carcinoma thyroid shows

  • Papillary projections
  • Orphan-Annie eyed nuclei (pale empty nuclei)
  • Psammoma bodies (microscopic calcified deposits)

Option B:

Follicular carcinoma thyroid on histopathology may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid (resembling normal thyroid gland) or sheets of cells without colloid.

Option D: Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology including giant cells or spindle shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese lady with diabetes presented to you for a routine checkup. She brings along reports of HbA1C which is 6.5 and lipid profile which shows TG-250mg/dl, LDL-160mg/dl, and HDL-45mg/dl. She is maintaining well on Metformin 500mg and Glibenclamide 5mg and Atorvastatin 20mg. On examination, she has a pulse of 70bpm and a BP of 160/90mmHg. You start her on Telmisartan 20mg for her hypertension and ask her to follow up after 1 month. She however presented one week later with complaints of anxiety, sweating, palpitation, weakness. Her BP is 150/90mmHg and her pulse is 90bpm. Her blood glucose was measured to be 50mg/dl. Prompt administration of glucose solution was done which relived the symptoms. A history revealed she had started taking aspirin for her toothache on the advice of a local chemist. Which of the following is responsible for her symptoms?

choices.text: Aspirin decreases the antihypertensive effect of telmisartan resulting in symptoms of anxiety and palpitations
Telmisartan predisposes to statin toxicity resulting in the current symptoms
Combination of statins and aspirin causes cardiovascular potentiation and resulted in anxiety and palpitations
Aspirin potentiates the action of glibenclamide causing hypoglycemia

questions.solution:
The clinical history of this patient on multiple medications including sulfonylureas(glibenclamide) presenting with hypoglycemia, points towards potentiation of its action, most likely due to aspirin. Aspirin is known to displace sulfonylureas out of plasma protein binding, resulting in toxicity-like features of glibenclamide.

Antidiabetic Drugs that pose a risk of leading to hypoglycemia (insulin secretagogue):

  • Sulfonylureas
  • Meglitinides: Nateglinide, Repaglinide

Sulfonylureas are known to interact with multiple medications as given below:

Drugs that increase the action of sulfonylureas

  • Displace from protein binding: Phenylbutazone, sulfinpyrazone, salicylates, sulfonamides.
  • Inhibit metabolism/excretion: Cimetidine, ketoconazole, sulfonamides, warfarin, chloramphenicol, acute alcohol intake (also synergizes by causing hypoglycemia).
  • Synergize with or prolong pharmacodynamic action: Salicylates, propranolol (cardioselective β1 blockers are less liable), lithium, theophylline, alcohol (by inhibiting gluconeogenesis).

Drugs that decrease the function of Sulfonylureas (worsen diabetes)

  • Induce metabolism: Phenobarbitone, phenytoin, rifampicin, chronic alcoholism.
  • Opposite action suppresses insulin release: Corticosteroids. thiazides, furosemide, oral contraceptives.

Other options

Aspirin might decrease the antihypertensive effect of ACE inhibitors or ARBs. However, these symptoms are known to be warning signs of hypoglycemia. Hence this interaction is less likely.

No interaction between telmisartan and atorvastatin resulting in increased toxicity of statin is known.

Aspirin is combined with statin without any interaction causing cardiovascular potentiation.
